misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Array Index Bounds Confusion (last index vs length)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the last element of an array of size n is at index n, and that accessing y[n] will retrieve the last entered value.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are zero-indexed. Valid indices are 0 through n-1. y[n] is always out of bounds and throws an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException at runtime. The last element is y[n-1], which must be saved before shifting.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) whenever n>0, so the program will not produce the required shifted output.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that an array of size n has valid indices from 0 to n (inclusive), and that accessing y[n] when the array has n elements is a valid operation that retrieves the last element.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are zero-indexed. An array of size n has valid indices from 0 to n-1. Accessing y[n] is an out-of-bounds access that throws an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException. The student's mental model does not account for the fact that array length and the maximum valid index are different by 1.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) when attempting to execute line 9 (int t=y[n];)

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that to access all n elements of an array, the loop counter should be initialized at 1 and run up to and including n, using the index i-1 to access y. This pattern is applied consistently throughout the code.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: While the pattern of using i=1 to i<=n with y[i-1] indexing does work for input and output loops, it creates confusion and makes the shift logic error (y[n] access) more likely. The idiomatic Java approach uses i=0 to i<n directly. Additionally, in the shift loop at line 10, initializing i=n and decrementing while i>1 leaves the loop early before processing all necessary elements, compounding the out-of-bounds error.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: The loop condition i>1 in the shift operation (line 10) stops one iteration too early, which combined with the out-of-bounds access at y[n], prevents correct execution.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that for an array of size N, the index of the final element is N.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-indexed. Therefore, an array declared with size 'n' has valid indices ranging from 0 to n-1. Attempting to access index 'n' results in an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException because it refers to the (n+1)-th position, which does not exist.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Array indexing off-by-one (confusing length with last index)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that an array of size n has its last valid element at index n, so reading y[n] should retrieve the last element for the wrap-around step.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-indexed. For an array of length n, valid indices are 0 through n-1. Accessing y[n] always throws ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException when n>0. The correct last element is y[n-1].
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) during the shift when n>0, so no shifted output is produced.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when an array has size n, the last element can be accessed at index y[n]. The student does not consistently apply the 0-indexed nature of Java arrays.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java arrays are 0-indexed. An array of size n has valid indices from 0 to n-1. The element y[n] does not exist and attempting to access it causes an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException. The student correctly uses i-1 when reading elements in the input loop (treating the loop counter i from 1 to n as 1-indexed), but fails to maintain this understanding when accessing the last element during the shift operation.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException at runtime when trying to execute line 8: int t=y[n];

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that in an array of size N, the index of the final element is N.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays use 0-based indexing. For an array of length n, the valid indices are 0 through n-1. Accessing index n results in an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.
